an10.68:4.1: At one time the Buddha stayed near Naḷakapāna in the parrot tree grove.
an10.68:4.2: Now, at that time it was the sabbath, and the Buddha was sitting surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
an10.68:4.3: The Buddha spent most of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dharma talk. Then he looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were so very silent. He addressed Venerable Sāriputta:
an10.68:5.1: “Sāriputta, the Saṅgha of mendicants is rid of dullness and drowsiness.
an10.68:5.2: Give them some Dharma talk as you feel inspired.
an10.68:6.1: And then the Buddha spread out his outer robe folded in four and lay down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
an10.68:7.1: “Reverends, whoever has no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom; who doesn’t want to listen, doesn’t memorize the teachings, examine their meaning, or practice accordingly, and is not diligent when it comes to wholesome qualities
an10.68:7.9: can expect decline, not growth, in wholesome qualities, whether by day or by night.
an10.68:7.10: It’s like the moon in the waning fortnight. Whether by day or by night, its beauty, roundness, light, and diameter and circumference only decline.
an10.68:7.11: In the same way, whoever has no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom; who doesn’t want to listen, doesn’t memorize the teachings, examine their meaning, or practice accordingly, and is negligent when it comes to wholesome qualities
an10.68:7.19: can expect decline, not growth, in wholesome qualities, whether by day or by night.
